choices.D: The datastore is a vSAN datastore.
choices.A: The datastore is formatted as VMFS3.
choices.C: The datastore is a raw device mapping.
choices.B: The datastore is formatted as VMFS6.

questions.question_text:
An administrator identifies a snapshot file named `Win10-000001-sesparse.vmdk` on a datastore.
Which type of information can be determined about this datastore?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is Correct

Selected Answer: B
SEsparse is a default format for all delta disks on the VMFS6 datastores. On VMFS5, SEsparse is used for virtual disks of the size 2 TB and larger.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.storage.doc/GUID-88E5A594-DEBC-4662-812F-EA421591C70F.html

Selected Answer: B
Kind of a trick question because it could also be a VMFS5 datastore but that's not one of the answers. SEsparse isn't a thing on VMFS3 or non-VMFS datastores like vSAN. VMFS6 is the best answer.

questions.question_text: Which two performance tools can be used to monitor virtual machines outside the guest operating system? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Correct: AD
Perfmon is an inside OS tool that's why it is wrong
esxtop is used to troubleshoot perf issues:
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.monitoring.doc/GUID-A31249BF-B5DC-455B-AFC7-7D0BBD6E37B6.html
Correct A and D, Perfom is inside OS

A and D are correct
Student guide 8-32 Resource-Monitoring Tools page 380

Just to confuse you all, esxtop can be set up to "forward metrics" to perfmon on any Win box, that does not need to be the VM which is being monitored... however its still a guest OS level monitoring which displays and logs it, but its not the one that actually monitors it :)
AD is the correct answer.

Selected Answer: AD
A and D are the answers
A & D correct. Passed with 500 today

Selected Answer: AD
A and D

Exam guide page 380
 Module 8-32 (Resource-Monitoring Tools )
Answer is A and C
Should be AD? E is a way to monitor windows only and the question is to monitor guest OSs in general

Selected Answer: AD
A nd D other tools are internal to the OS

Selected Answer: AD
E is wrong and Perfmon is Windows Guest OS tool
A&D correct

comments.content: those tool can only monitor from inside. The question is about tool that monitor Guest OS from outside. So A D is correct

discussion.content: For me is corret answer is C and E
A and D are correct, Perfmon is windows inbuild tool on its guest OS
A and D

Answer is D. Assuming you have a startup order.

https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2108294
Clearly states: The order in which virtual machines are shut down is the reverse of their startup order.
